questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the image given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dermoid

 

Ocular dermoids are choristomas, containing tissue not normally found in the area. They often appear as round, firm, and sometimes hair-bearing lesions on the surface of the eye or near the eyelids as given in the image. Dermoids can vary in size and may cause astigmatism if they press against the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pterygium: This is a benign growth of conjunctival tissue that extends onto the cornea. It often presents as a wedge-shaped, fleshy growth and is usually found on the side closest to the nose. Pterygium is often associated with exposure to sunlight or wind, and its symptoms can include redness, irritation, or a feeling of something in the eye.

 

Option B. Pinguecula: Similar to a pterygium, a pinguecula is a benign, yellowish growth that occurs on the conjunctiva. It typically appears on the side of the eye nearest to the nose but does not grow onto the cornea. Pingueculae are also associated with long-term sun exposure and can cause irritation or dryness.

 

Option D. Dermolipoma: This is a type of choristoma, like dermoids, but it primarily consists of fatty tissue. Dermolipomas are usually located on the outer corner of the eye and appear as soft, yellowish masses. They are generally benign and asymptomatic, but their size and location can occasionally cause cosmetic or functional concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and differentiating between various ocular surface lesions is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management. This involves understanding their typical presentations, etiologies, and potential complications. Regular eye examinations and proper eye protection, especially from UV light, are important for eye health.

questions.text: In extroversion, what is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus muscle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left medial rectus

 

The yoke muscle of the right LR is the left MR.

 

Yoke muscles are the primary muscles in each eye that accomplish a given version (eg, for right gaze, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus muscles).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left superior oblique: This muscle is involved in intorsion, depression, and abduction of the left eye, not in coordinating rightward gaze with the right lateral rectus.

 

Option C. Left inferior rectus: This muscle is responsible for depression and adduction of the left eye, not relevant to the rightward gaze.

 

Option D. Left superior rectus: This muscle is involved in elevation and intorsion of the left eye, not in the horizontal movement to the right.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In extroversion (rightward gaze), the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus (which abducts the right eye) is the left medial rectus (which adducts the left eye), enabling coordinated horizontal movement.

questions.text: Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by which organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ancylostoma braziliense

 

Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by Ancylostoma braziliense.

 

Cutaneous larva migrans or ground itch or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

The most common cause is non-human species of Hookworm Ancylostoma braziliense and A. caninum.

 

Larva currens – Strongyloides stercolaris

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercolaris: Incorrect, although Strongyloides stercolaris can cause skin symptoms (known as larva currens) due to the rapid migration of larvae, it is not the most common cause of cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option B. Toxocara canis: Incorrect, this organism causes toxocariasis or visceral larva migrans, primarily affecting organs and causing systemic symptoms, rather than the localized skin manifestations seen in cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: Incorrect, this is a human hookworm that primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms upon infection, not cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ancylostoma braziliense is the primary cause of cutaneous larva migrans, a condition where the migration of hookworm larvae in the skin results in distinctive creeping eruptions. This condition is a reminder of the zoonotic potential of certain parasites and underscores the importance of preventive measures, especially in areas where pets are likely to be infected.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes this?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Niacin

 

This is Casal’s necklace shown in picture, which occurs in Vitamin B3/ Niacin deficiency. Niacin can be formed in the body from amino acid tryptophan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Thiamine is an essential B-vitamin that plays a crucial role in energy metabolism. It helps the body convert food (carbohydrates) into energy (ATP). Thiamine is important for the proper functioning of nerves and muscles. Deficiency can lead to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which affect the nervous system.

 

Option C. Zinc: Zinc is a trace mineral that is crucial for the immune system, wound healing, and DNA synthesis. It also plays a role in maintaining a sense of taste and smell. Zinc deficiency can lead to impaired immune function, delayed wound healing, and other health issues. It is an essential nutrient for overall health.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine is another B-vitamin that is involved in various metabolic processes, including amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis. It plays a role in maintaining brain health and proper nerve function. Pyridoxine deficiency can lead to symptoms like anemia, nerve damage, and skin issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin is another B-vitamin that is essential for various bodily functions. It plays a role in converting nutrients into energy, creating cholesterol and fats, repairing DNA, and acting as an antioxidant. Niacin is important for overall metabolic health. Severe niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which can have serious effects on the skin, digestive system, and nervous system.

 

Niacin deficiency can be caused by:

  • Dietary deficiency of tryptophan
  • Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency
  • Carcinoid syndrome
  • Hartnup’s disease

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

 

  • Tilt the patient’s head back by pushing down on the forehead.
  • Place the tips of your index and middle fingers under the chin and pull up on the mandible (not on the soft tissues). This lifts the tongue away from the posterior pharynx and improves airway patency.

 

There is no absolute contraindication to it but Suspected cervical injury is a relative contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: Lift the mandible upward with your fingers, at least until the lower incisors are higher than the upper incisors. This maneuver lifts the tongue along with the mandible, thus relieving upper airway obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Manual inline stabilization: is a neck immobilisation technique in a natural position achieved by using the fingers and palms of both hands to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to gently counteract the forces of airway intervention

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The head-tilt chin-lift maneuver is a key technique for opening the airway in emergency situations, especially when cervical spine injury is not suspected.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Barium meal

 

Explanation:

 

The given image is a barium meal. This study is used to examine the stomach and proximal duodenum.

 

Visual Cues: The image shows the distribution of barium within the stomach, outlining its contours and revealing its internal structure, which is typical in a barium meal examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barium Swallow: This study primarily evaluates the esophagus and does not extend into the stomach. The radiograph showing the stomach filled with barium indicates that the procedure goes beyond just a barium swallow.

 

Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through: This investigation involves not only the stomach but also a sequential imaging of the small intestine as the barium passes through. The specific image provided does not show barium beyond the proximal duodenum, which is typical in a simple barium meal.

 

Option D. Barium Enema: This procedure is used to visualize the large intestine (colon) and rectum using barium introduced via the rectum. The provided image showing the stomach filled with barium clearly indicates that it's not a barium enema.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room after consuming 8 digoxin tablets. On examination, he was found to be unstable, with a heart rate of 56 beats per minute. An ECG revealed a third-degree heart block. What is the next step in this patient's care? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digoxin Immune Fab

 

For the management of Digoxin toxicity having the features of Bradycardia and a 3rd degree heart block, we need to administer Digibind, which is an antibody against Digoxin. It is also known as Digoxin immune Fab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lidocaine: Lidocaine is used to treat Ventricular Tachycardia or Ventricular Fibrillation.

 

Option C. DC cardioversion: DC cardioversion is used for tachyarrhythmias when pharmacologic treatment fails. It is not used in bradyarrhythmias.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is an antiepileptic used for the treatment of GTCS. It can also be used as a class Ib antiarrhythmic drug for the treatment of Digoxin induced Ventricular Tachycardia, or any polymorphic ventricular tachycardia due to QT prolongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The administration of Digoxin Immune Fab is the next step in the management of life-threatening digoxin toxicity, particularly in the presence of bradycardia and third-degree heart block.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dihydrobiopterin reductase

 

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder where phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, cannot be properly metabolized due to enzyme deficiencies. In classical PKU, the deficiency is in phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, if phenylalanine hydroxylase levels are normal, as stated in the question, the problem lies elsewhere in the metabolic pathway. Dihydrobiopterin reductase is an enzyme that regenerates tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor necessary for phenylalanine hydroxylase function. If dihydrobiopterin reductase is deficient, tetrahydrobiopterin cannot be regenerated, leading to non-classical PKU despite normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tyrosine transaminase: This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of tyrosine, not in the initial conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine or the regeneration of tetrahydrobiopterin, making it unrelated to PKU.

 

Option C. Dopa decarboxylase: This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of neurotransmitters like dopamine from DOPA, unrelated to phenylalanine metabolism or PKU.

 

Option D. Tyrosine hydroxylase: This enzyme converts tyrosine to DOPA and is involved in neurotransmitter synthesis, not in phenylalanine metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In non-classical phenylketonuria, the deficiency is in dihydrobiopterin reductase, not phenylalanine hydroxylase.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old patient who has presented with easily rupturing flaccid bulla on the skin and whose biopsy indicates a suprabasal split?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Based on the clinical presentation of bullous lesions and the histologic finding of a suprabasal blister, Pemphigus vulgaris is suspected.
  • This condition involves the production of antibodies, particularly against Desmoglein 3, and sometimes Desmoglein 1. These antibodies are typically of the IgG type. Desmoglein 3 is primarily found in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa.
  • As a result, patients exhibit flaccid bullae on the skin, and mucosal involvement, especially in the oral mucosa, is common.

 

 

  • Ulceration may also occur in other areas such as the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, and larynx. Cutaneous lesions are more frequently observed on the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vegetans:

  • Description: Pemphigus vegetans is a variant of pemphigus vulgaris. It features vesicles and bullae that evolve into verrucous (wart-like) lesions, particularly in skin folds.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The primary presentation in the question doesn't describe verrucous or wart-like lesions.

 

Option C. Pemphigus foliaceus:

  • Description: Pemphigus foliaceus is another type of pemphigus but is characterized by more superficial skin blisters than pemphigus vulgaris, and it doesn't typically involve the mucous membranes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The biopsy of pemphigus foliaceus would show a split in the upper epidermis (subcorneal), not a suprabasal split.

 

Option D. Erythema multiforme:

  • Description: Erythema multiforme is an acute, immune-mediated skin condition. It is characterized by target-like lesions and is often triggered by infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus) or certain medications.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The presentation of erythema multiforme is quite distinct with its target-like lesions, and a biopsy would not reveal a suprabasal split.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is identified by the presence of flaccid bullae that rupture easily and a suprabasal split on biopsy, indicating an autoimmune process causing loss of epidermal cell adhesion.

 

 

Reference: 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 47.1-47.5, 50.1-50.10

Online resources:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3884912/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17619399/

questions.text: What is the approximate time interval between HIV infection & manifestation of AIDS? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 10 years

 

The typical time interval from HIV infection to the manifestation of AIDS, in the absence of antiretroviral therapy, is approximately 10 years. This period is often referred to as the latency period, during which the virus is actively replicating in the body, but the immune system has not yet deteriorated to the point of clinical AIDS. This period can vary based on several factors, including the individual's genetic predisposition, co-infections, and overall health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mean interval b/w infection to AIDS is due to prolonged latency period (~10- years).

 

Reference - Harrison/HIV/Chap 201

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 18 weeks of gestation. On abdominal examination, the uterine size was found to correspond to 16 weeks of gestation. On US, oligohydramnios was found. Which of the following is a likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like
    • B/l renal agenesis
    • B/l dysplastic kidneys
    • B/l Autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal anemia: Severe fetal anemia also can cause hydrops and polyhydramnios like in Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome and Rh iso-immunization

 

Option C. Barter syndrome and option D. Anencephaly cause polyhydramnios

 

Educational Objective

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like bilateral renal agenesis, bilateral dysplastic kidneys, or bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease.

 

Ref: Page no 352, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less
Decreased release of 02
It has less P50
It is less acidic

questions.text: What makes CPDA superior than ACD for blood storage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less

 

Explanation

 

The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less when the blood is stored in CPDA compared with ACD.

 

The ease with which hemoglobin releases oxygen to the tissues is controlled by erythrocytic 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) such that an increase in the concentration of 2,3-DPG decreases oxygen affinity and vice versa.

 

In stored blood, the 2,3 DPG levels usually fall, thus less oxygen is released to the tissues. Therefore, its use in hypoxic patients (E.g., anemia) is limited.

 

Phosphate-containing solution like CPDA (Citrate, phosphate, dextrose, adenine) prevents the fall in 2.3DPG levels. Higher 2,3 DPG concentration decreases affinity of Hb to the oxygen releasing oxygen to the tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased release of O2: Incorrect. The goal of effective blood storage solutions like CPDA is to ensure that the oxygen release capacity is maintained, not decreased. CPDA helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG, which enhances the release of oxygen to tissues.

 

Option C. It has less P50: Incorrect. P50 is a measure of the oxygen tension at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated with oxygen. A higher P50, indicative of lower oxygen affinity, is preferable in stored blood as it means oxygen is more readily released to tissues—a trait supported by higher 2,3-DPG levels.

 

Option D. It is less acidic: Incorrect. While pH maintenance is important in blood storage, the primary benefit of CPDA over ACD is not related to less acidity but to its inclusion of phosphate and adenine, which help sustain energy (ATP) production and 2,3-DPG levels in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of CPDA in blood storage is superior to ACD due to its phosphate content, which helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG in stored red blood cells. This biochemical preservation is crucial for ensuring that transfused blood can effectively release oxygen to hypoxic tissues, making CPDA the preferred choice in clinical settings where blood transfusions are necessary.

questions.text:
You are employed at a primary health center (PHC) located in an area with a high risk of earthquakes. What actions would you take to ensure readiness for potential emergencies? [NEET PG 2022]

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1,2,3

 

To ensure readiness for potential emergencies in a high-risk earthquake area, the following actions are crucial:

 

  1. Disaster Preparedness: Ensuring all financial and other resources are available. This involves mobilizing funds and resources for quick evacuation and emergency response.
  2. Increase Public Awareness: Conducting campaigns and using loudspeakers to inform the public about earthquake preparedness measures and safety protocols.
  3. Conduct a Simulation: Performing disaster simulations and assessing the response to identify areas for improvement and ensure the effectiveness of the emergency plan.

 

These steps are essential components of a comprehensive disaster preparedness strategy and done by someone working in a PHC situated in a high seismic zone. A medical officer is supposed to provide instructions by any communication method possible to manage through the calamity.

 

Roles and responsibilities of medical officer of PHC when posted in Seismic areas

 

  • Ensure funds and resources are available and can be mobilized at the time of disaster for quick evacuation
  • Preparedness to handle emergency
  • Disaster simulation practices and then check the response

 

Other Options:

 

While following instructions from higher officials is important during an actual disaster, it is not a proactive preparedness measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency preparedness is a programme of long-term development activities whose goals are to strengthen the overall capacity and capability of a country to manage efficiently all types of emergency. It involves the following steps:

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Evaluate the risk of disaster
  5. Information sessions coordination with news media
  6. Adopt standards and regulations

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multiple anogenital warts, and the biopsy reveals squamous atypia. Among the various human papillomavirus types, which ones are classified as high-risk? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HPV 18

 

Explanation:

 

  • Squamous carcinoma is the most prevalent type of cancer associated with HPV infection.
  • Among the various human papillomavirus types, HPV-16 and HPV-18 are considered high-risk and are frequently implicated in the development of cervical, vaginal, and vulval cancers.
  • Other high-risk types include HPV-31, HPV-33, and HPV-35.
  • Genital warts, also known as condyloma acuminata or venereal warts, are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6) and human papillomavirus 11 (HPV-11). These types, referred to as low-risk, have a lower potential to lead to malignancy.

 

Genital warts are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact, although non-sexual transmission is also possible.

 

 

Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are first-line medications prescribed for the treatment of genital warts.

 

IMIQUIMOD:

 

  • Imiquimod cream uses:
    • Actinic keratoses
    • Superficial basal cell carcinoma
    • Genital warts (topical immunomodulation)
       
  • Mechanism of action: Activates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, leading to apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A HPV 2:

  • This type is considered low-risk and is commonly associated with common warts that affect the hands and feet, not with anogenital warts or cancer.

 

Option C & D HPV 6 and HPV 11:

  • These are both low-risk types that are associated with about 90% of genital warts but are not typically linked with cancer.
  • They are known to cause benign conditions like respiratory papillomatosis as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HPV 16 & 18 as high-risk types associated with anogenital cancers, and recognize that HPV 2, 6, and 11 are low-risk types not typically associated with cancer.
  • It’s crucial to know the distinction between low-risk and high-risk HPV types due to the differences in prognosis and management.
  • High-risk types warrant more aggressive monitoring and management due to their association with malignancy.

 

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43, 25.55

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 198

Shaws textbook of gynaecology 16th edition 156, 157, 486

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 650

 

Online resources:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9434721/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK321770/

questions.text: A child with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis has multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is likely to be seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypochloremic, hypokalemic alkalosis

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is a condition where there is constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet due to hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus. This results in persistent vomiting, which leads to the loss of hydrogen and chloride ions in the gastric acid and potassium ions in the gastric mucus. As a consequence, the multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting in IHPS can cause hypochloremia and hypokalemia, leading to alkalosis.

 

Cause of metabolic alkalosis: The hydrogen ions that normally reach the duodenum are now lost due to vomiting. Hence, the bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas is decreased, thereby increasing the bicarbonate levels in the serum.

 

Causes of hypokalemia:

 

  • Because of alkalosis, the hydrogen ions exit from the cells in exchange for potassium leading to hypokalemia.
  • Loss of fluid due to excessive vomiting activates the RAAS pathway. This worsens hypokalemia as the aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for the secretion of K* and H* ions into the urine. The loss of H* ions in urine lowers the urinary pH, resulting in paradoxical aciduria

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis leads to hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to persistent vomiting and loss of gastric acid.

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest X-ray image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coeur en sabot

 

Chest X-ray image describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

 

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot ("Coeur-en sabot").
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Egg on side appearance: Egg on string appearance is seen in transposition of great arteries (TGA)

 

Option C. Egg on string appearance: Scimitar sign is seen in Scimitar syndrome which is also known as partial anomalous pulmonary venous return.

 

Option D. Snowman sign: Snowman sign is seen in supracardiac TAPVC

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which results from right ventricular hypertrophy, leading to the distinctive cardiac silhouette.

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient who is on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clotrimazole

 

The given clinical scenario of white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa in a patient using inhalational steroids points to diagnosis of oral candidiasis and drug that can be used for the treatment is clotrimazole.

 

Asthma patients use MDI which can result in deposition of steroids in the oropharyngeal space, which might lead to cough, dysphonia, and oral candidiasis.

 

Clotrimazole is classified under Azole group of Anti-Fungal drugs, acts by inhibiting fungal sterol (ergosterol) synthesis. Used topically in treatment for topical fungal infections like tinea and candida

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is mainly used against dermatophytes and is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. But it is not effective against Candida.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Terbinafine acts by inhibiting the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase. which reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. Used to treat nail onychomycosis and other dermatophytosis.

 

Option D. Flucytosine: Flucytosine acts by inhibiting nucleic acid synthesis. Used exclusively to combat systemic fungal infections (e.g., cryptococcal meningitis) in combination with amphotericin B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clotrimazole is the drug of choice for treating oral candidiasis, especially in patients who develop the condition as a side effect of inhalational steroid use. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis, compromising the fungal cell membrane integrity.

questions.text: Giving TPN (total para-enteral nutrition) in a patient in ICU with metabolic syndrome predisposes to: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperglycemia


Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a patient with metabolic syndrome predisposes to hyperglycemia. Metabolic syndrome is characterized by insulin resistance, often seen in conditions such as type 2 diabetes, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and, in some cases, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Insulin resistance impairs the body’s ability to utilize glucose efficiently. When TPN, which is high in glucose, is administered, the already compromised insulin response leads to elevated blood glucose levels, resulting in hyperglycemia. This is a common complication in patients receiving TPN, especially those with underlying metabolic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reactive Hypoglycemia: Reactive hypoglycemia is a condition where blood glucose levels drop excessively after eating, due to an overproduction of insulin. It is not typically associated with TPN or metabolic syndrome, as TPN administration generally leads to hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia due to insulin resistance.

 

Option C. Hyperlipidemia: While hyperlipidemia is a component of metabolic syndrome, it is not a direct complication specifically associated with TPN. Although TPN can contain lipids, its primary complication related to metabolic syndrome is hyperglycemia due to glucose intolerance.

 

Option D. Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia, characterized by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood, can be associated with metabolic syndrome but is not directly induced by TPN administration. The primary metabolic disturbance from TPN in these patients is related to glucose management rather than uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In patients with metabolic syndrome, TPN can exacerbate hyperglycemia due to pre-existing insulin resistance. This underscores the need for careful monitoring of blood glucose levels and management of insulin requirements in these patients.

questions.text: The cross product ratio can be obtained by: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Case control study

 

The cross-product ratio is a measure of association between two categorical variables, and it can be arrived at from a case-control study.

 

In a case-control study, the odds ratio (OR) is often used as a measure of association between the exposure and the outcome. The cross-product ratio is an alternative measure of association that can be derived from the odds ratio.

 

Interpretation

 

OR> 1 → Association Present

OR =1 → No Association

OR< 1 → Inverse/Negative Association → RF is protective(beneficial)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ecological study: This type of study examines the associations between exposure and outcomes at the population or group level, not at the individual level, and does not typically use the cross-product ratio.

 

Option B. Cohort study: This type of study follows a group of exposed and non-exposed individuals over time to observe the incidence of outcomes. It uses relative risk rather than the cross-product ratio.

 

Option C. Cross-sectional study: This study observes a population at a single point in time, assessing both exposure and outcome simultaneously. It can measure prevalence but not the cross-product ratio specifically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cross-product ratio, or odds ratio, is a measure of association commonly derived from case-control studies to determine the relationship between exposure and outcome.

choices.text: Environmental enteropathy
Celiac disease
Whipple's disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

The clinical presentation and histopathological findings point to celiac disease.

 

Celiac disease is sometimes referred to as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. In genetically predisposed individuals, it is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the consumption of gluten-containing cereals such as Barley, Rye, Oat & Wheat (BROW)

 

Almost all celiac disease patients have the class II HLADQ2 or HLA-DQ8 allele.

 

Histopathology: Increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy characterize the histopathology.

 

 

  • Prior to biopsy, noninvasive serologic tests are usually performed. The presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin is the most sensitive test. Anti-endomysial antibodies are more specific than other antibodies but less sensitive.
  • Clinical features: -
    • Malabsorption syndrome with chronic refractory anemia, chronic diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. A characteristic itchy, blistering skin lesion, dermatitis herpetiformis, can be present in as many as 10% of patients, and the incidence of lymphocytic gastritis and lymphocytic colitis is also increased.
    • Enteropathy associated T cell lymphoma
    • Small intestinal adenocarcinoma

 

Treatment – Gluten free diet results in symptomatic improvement for most patients, but a gluten-free diet may also reduce the risk of long-term complications including anemia, female infertility, osteoporosis, and cancer.

 

DAPSONE for dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Environmental enteropathy: Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is seen in tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy. Folic acid and B12 deficiency is common.

 

Option C. Whipple's disease: Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T. whipplei. Small intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages (see image below).

 

 

Option D. Chronic pancreatitis: Causes malabsorption due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Not associated with the specific histopathological features seen in celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is characterized by malabsorption, diarrhea, poor appetite, crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes. It is diagnosed by serologic tests and confirmed with a duodenal biopsy. Treatment includes a strict gluten-free diet.

questions.text: Which glands can be involved in Bromhidrosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both Apocrine and Eccrine Glands

 

  • Bromhidrosis refers to offensive body odor originating from apocrine and eccrine sweat glands.
  • Specifically, bromhidrosis affects "Apocrine (Axilla) or Eccrine (Feet)" glands. 
  • While apocrine glands produce odorous secretions containing pheromones associated with body odor (particularly in axillary regions), eccrine glands can also be affected, especially on the feet. 
  • The interaction between sweat and bacteria on the skin surface leads to the breakdown of sweat components, resulting in malodorous compounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apocrine Sweat Glands only: 

 

  • While apocrine glands are commonly associated with body odor due to their secretions containing pheromones, bromhidrosis isn't limited to these glands alone. 
  • This would be correct if bromhidrosis only affected the axillary region.

 

Option B. Eccrine Sweat Glands only: 

 

  • Eccrine glands can cause bromhidrosis, particularly on the feet, but this option is incomplete since apocrine glands are also involved. 
  • This would be correct if bromhidrosis only affected the feet.

 

Option C. Sebaceous Glands: 

 

  • Sebaceous glands produce sebum through holocrine secretion and function to lubricate skin and hair. 
  • They aren't primarily responsible for bromhidrosis. 
  • These glands are associated with conditions like acne vulgaris rather than body odor.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Bromhidrosis (offensive body odor) can originate from both apocrine glands (primarily in axillary regions) and eccrine glands (commonly on feet), resulting from bacterial decomposition of sweat components on the skin surface.

questions.text: The green-shaded region in the coronal section of the brain corresponds to which type of fibers? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Projection

 

The internal capsule, a type of projection fibre, is the marked structure.

 

Projection fibres -

 

  • Connect the cerebral cortex to other brain areas and the spinal cord.
  • These fibers run vertically, either ascending to the cortex (afferent fibers bringing in sensory information) or descending from the cortex (efferent fibers sending out motor commands).
  • The corona radiata and the internal capsule are examples of areas containing many projection fibers.
  • They facilitate communication between the cortex and other parts of the CNS like the brainstem, thalamus, and spinal cord.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Short Association:

 

  • Also known as "U-fibers" or "short arcuate fibers" which connect neighboring gyrus.
  • They allow for communication between adjacent or nearby cortical regions.
  • Primarily found in the gray matter just below the cortical surface.
  • Their presence helps in localized processing and integration of information within a single cerebral hemisphere.

 

Option B. Long Association:

 

  • Connect more distant areas within the same hemisphere.
  • Examples include the superior longitudinal fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the posterior temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, and the uncinate fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the anterior temporal lobe.
  • These fibers are crucial for integrating information across distant cortical areas within the same hemisphere.

 

Option D. Commissural:

 

  • Connect corresponding regions of the two cerebral hemispheres, allowing them to communicate with each other.
  • The most prominent example is the corpus callosum, which is the largest white matter structure in the brain and provides a broad band of neural connections between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. Other examples include the anterior commissure and the posterior commissure.
  • These fibers are essential for the two hemispheres to share information and coordinate activity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with cough and congestion in the chest. He is a known case of atrial fibrillation (AF) and on examination, he had an irregularly irregular pulse and ECG showed AF with a heart rate of 52/min. His current medications are KCl 10 mEq BID, Triamterene, ASA 100mg/day, Atenolol 50 mg BID, and Clarithromycin. Two months ago, his digoxin levels were 1.5 ng/mL and currently, it rose to 3.4 ng/mL. Which of the following is responsible for such an increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Clarithromycin

 

The patient is experiencing elevated digoxin levels, which is likely due to a drug-drug interaction. Digoxin is a medication used to treat various heart conditions, including atrial fibrillation. It has a narrow therapeutic index, meaning that even small changes in its levels can lead to toxicity.

 

Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that inhibits the enzyme cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP3A4). Digoxin is partially metabolized by CYP3A4. When clarithromycin inhibits this enzyme, it can lead to decreased metabolism of digoxin, resulting in elevated digoxin levels and potential toxicity. This interaction can explain the significant increase in the patient's digoxin levels from 1.5 ng/mL to 3.4 ng/mL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triamterene: Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic and does not typically interact with digoxin in a way that would cause elevated digoxin levels. It is not known to inhibit the metabolism of digoxin.

 

Option B. KCl: Potassium chloride (KCl) supplementation is often given to prevent hypokalemia, which can enhance the toxic effects of digoxin. However, KCl does not directly interact with digoxin to increase its serum levels. Instead, it helps mitigate digoxin toxicity by maintaining normal potassium levels.

 

Option D. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker and does not interact with digoxin to increase its serum levels. While it can affect heart rate, it does not interfere with the metabolism or excretion of digoxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarithromycin, by inhibiting CYP3A4, can significantly elevate digoxin levels, leading to toxicity. When prescribing medications, it is essential to consider potential drug-drug interactions, especially with drugs like digoxin that have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: Which drug is used for mass chemoprophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ciprofloxacin

 

Ciprofloxacin is commonly used for mass chemoprophylaxis in cases of meningococcal meningitis, particularly among close contacts of an infected individual. It is effective in preventing the spread of Neisseria meningitidis, the bacterium responsible for meningococcal disease. Ciprofloxacin is preferred due to its broad-spectrum activity, ease of administration as a single-dose regimen, and good penetration into the cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloramphenicol: While used for treatment of meningococcal meningitis, it is not used for chemoprophylaxis.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Not used in the prophylaxis or treatment of meningococcal meningitis.

 

Option D. Penicillin: Although used for treatment, penicillin is not typically used for prophylaxis against meningococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciprofloxacin, Rifampicin, Ceftriaxone is indicated in the chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis for close contacts to prevent secondary cases.

 

Ceftriaxone is preferred in children < 18 years and pregnancy.
